Yes, our best hope is that this fiasco inspires the GOP to find a way to jettison these yahoos.  The leadership must dread having this happen again.

Those who were selected in smoke filled rooms might not survive in today's 24-7 news cycle.  Electronic surveillance was non-existent when our best presidents were selected.  And the smoke filled rooms resulted in some real losers too.

If I remember correctly, Plato said that the one guy who should NOT get the job of leading the state is the guy who actively seeks it. He's almost certainly got the wrong reasons. The preferable leader is the reluctant philosopher-king who doesn't want the job because he understands the magnitude of the responsibility. Since no one has figured out how to ensure that the benevolent-despot system favoured  by the Republic will produce a despot who is, in fact, benevolent and remains so once he ascends the throne--Lord Acton's dictum that absolutely power corrupts absolutely comes into play--there's really no good way to implement Plato's suggestion.

You are entirely correct about the "kind of person too frequently drawn to high-level office and about traits that often abet his rise." However, you err to focus just on these two.

Our system of open primaries is based on self selection. Those who select themselves by definition have huge egos. They then must raise money, to promote their egos. The ones who can raise the most money for self promotion go on to office.

This is a system which selects for the "extreme narcissist." That is what such a system must produce. The self regard starts it, and the ability to manipulate better than others for self promotion advances it.

The old smoke filled rooms were a real problem, but they did not produce this sort of person. The fix for that problem created this problem.

We need to get away from self selection, advanced by self promotion with private money. The way our parties are set up now, the way our politics operates now, produces these guys routinely, predictably, and almost nothing but these types.

"The great unwashed" ... love it!

I'm just back from my sixth trip to India. From my very first visit I fell in love with the culture and the color and the people and the animals and the chaos. I deplore the filth [piles of garbage and human waste everywhere] and the corruption [pervasive at every level] and the "mañana" attitude [I think "patience" in dealing with India's idiosyncrasies dodges the real need to do away with the bureaucracy that strangles India's efforts to grow] , but somehow I can see past it. Others can't. All they can see is, in the words of one now non friend, "the great unwashed." To be distracted by that and miss out on 50,000 years of past history, the beauty, and the current growth is, to my mind, a terrible loss.

It seems that the part of the problem overshadowing the development of the Tablet, Akash, is politicizing of the project with good intention. There is an established architecture for the Tablets and only the various components can be selected optimally to reduce the cost. If the home work was done and a prototype was developed in IIT labs before rushing to manufacture on a large scale, the whole embassing mess could have been avoided and IIT Bombay would not have to start from scratch. Like many Government projects tend to be embedded with a dose of propaganda. Case in point is rural electrification. One can see poles and wires connecting villages to supply electricity power.It is all visible and looks good to outside visitor. But, there may not be a distribution transformer to supply power to the villages. Even if one has transformer, it burnts out prematurely due to lack of quality control. On the top of it, most of the time there is no enough power available to supply to the villages. Due to poor planning like in case of Akash, many policized project like one cited above results wasting of invaluable scarce resources and money.
Every cloud has a silver lining. There are several approaches one can take to accomplish a challenging task like Akash Project. I surely have hopes pinned on the team.

Barnes & Noble already have a Nook Simple Touch and Nook Tablet which have two different, "incompatible" environments; this doesn't pose a problem currently. I don't think that adding an option at purchase of choosing between Win 8 and Android for the Nook Tablet will upset any balances. Microsoft does not currently have exclusive rights to invest in the Nook division, so this is more than likely the future for the Nook Tablet. Win 8 for ARM already supports the Nook Tablet hardware, so it would relatively easy to offer both Operating Systems as choices.

Thanks very much for this piece. Our former house near Stull, Kansas, had a tree growing in an abandoned silo. We weren't farmers, but we were very interested in the still ongoing transition to sustainable agriculture. We were not as despairing of rural poverty or the decline of the family farm as perhaps we should have been. But we thought we had pretty much cornered the market on turkey vultures, hawks, and owls using our silo and that hackberry tree as their private air space until we read this piece which we enjoyed very much.

There is widespread speculation (and formidable evidence oft cited by this outlet) that Pakistani intelligence is complicit in targeted attacks against the Government of Afghanistan as well as against NATO Forces in Afghanistan. Though there is certainly a disconnect between the civilian government of Pakistan and the military/intelligence leadership that would approve such terrorist activity, the demand for an apology concerning a military friendly fire incident on the border is highly hypocritical, to say the least.  Taken as a singular event, I could see how a Pakistani citizen would demand an apology.  Yet, when considered against the current geopolitical situation, when put in the context of a Pakistani Defense establishment that supports enemies of the United States, when it is noted that the majority of Pakistanis vocally support the Afghan Taliban, and when one examines Pakistan's own reaction to terrorist attacks that it's citizens and operatives carry out against other nations, it is hard to come to the conclusion that Pakistan is deserving of any apology.  One might argue that Pakistan itself is overdue on a number of apologies: for supporting and failing to persecute the Haqqani Network; for failing to prevent the Mumbai attacks and failing to attack LeT; for not adequately searching for OBL; for allowing the Afghan Taliban to attack into Afghanistan from within Pakistan, etc. But I don't think we should be demanding any apologies--it's not good for diplomacy.
